File.Title: The Ventral Striatopallidothalamic Projection: I. The Striatopallidal Link Originating in the Striatal Parts of the Olfactory Tubercle
File.Authors: L. HEIMER, L. ZABORSZKY, D.S. ZAHM, AND G.F. ALHEID

Abstract.S: The projections from the striatal part of the olfactory tubercle were examined in rats, both with the aid of experimental silver impregnation methods following superficial laminar heat lesions of the tubercle and by the use of anterograde transport of Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHAL) following injections of the lectin in the dense cell layer of the tubercle.

Retrograde transport of fluorescent substances following injections of the tracer in the multiform layer of the tubercle were used to corroborate the results obtained by the anterograde transport and degeneration methods.

The main and apparently only significant termination from the striatal cells in the olfactory tubercle is located immediately deep to the dense cell layer in areas that could be identified as part of the ventral pallidum on the basis of either the Nissl method or glutamate decarboxylase immunocytochemistry.

Whereas a mediolateral topography is generally maintained by the ventral striatopallidal pathway originating in the dense cell layer, there is a considerable spread of the projection in the rostrocaudal direction.

The dense projection field of the olfactory tubercle component of the ventral striatopallidal pathway permeates the ventrolateral part of the ventral pallidum, thereby complementing the termination of the accumbens projection to the more mediodorsal parts of the ventral pallidum.

Introduction.S: The rodent olfactory tubercle (Tu) is a complex structure.
Its cells encompass a broad spectrum of sizes and shapes with medium and large neurons as the predominant forms.

In addition, there are striking aggregates of tightly packed small cells in the islands of Calleja and in the cap-regions of the dense cell layer (e.g., Fallon et al., 83; Millhouse and Heimer, 84; Heimer et al., 85).

Because Nissl-stained sections of the Tu give the impression of a laminated structure and because the Tu, like the neighboring primary olfactory (piriform) cortex, receives olfactory bulb projections, the Tu has generally been considered part of the olfactory cortex (e.g., Crosby and Humphrey, 41; Heimer, 68; Haberly and Price, 78).
A major input to the Tu, furthermore, consists of fibers from the olfactory cortex (Haberly and Price, 78).

However, the apparent lack of a reciprocal pathway from the Tu back to primary olfactory cortex is not in harmony with the notion that the Tu represents a cortical structure (Heimer and van Hoesen, 79).

Specifically, we have proposed that the medium-sized cell territories of the Tu represent a ventral part of the striatum (Heimer and Wilson, '75; Heimer, '78; Heimer and van Hoesen, ' 7 9 Heimer et al., '82; Heimer et al., '85).

In terms of connectivity, pathways from the allocortex (Heimer, '72), the intralaminar thalamic nuclei (Newman and Winans, '80; Beckstead, '84; Zaborszky et al., '85), the amygdaloid body (Krettek and Price, '781, and the dopaminergic cell groups of the ventral tegmental area (Fuxe, '65; Ungerstedt, '71; Hedreen and Chalmers, '72), which converge on the Tu, are more consistent with a striatal than cortical system of afTerents.

Fibers reported to originate in the superficial dense cell layer of Tu, and that terminate in a rostroventral part of the globus pallidus (i.e., the "ventral pallidum," Heimer and Wilson, "75), also argue in favor of considering the superficial medium-sized cell territories as part of striatum (Heimer et al., '75; GoldSchmidt and Heimer, '80; Zaborszky et al., '82).
The following report is a comprehensive description of the ventral striatopallidal pathway originating in the Tu.

The results produced by reduced silver impregnation techniques following superficial, laminar heat lesions of the Tu have been supplemented by a description of the anterograde transport of the plant lectin, Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L), from neurons in the superficial laminae of the Tu.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
General
All surgery was performed under general anesthesia using either sodium pentobarbital (50 mgkg) or Chloropent@ (3.3 mlkg).
Male Sprague-Dawley albino rats were used for all experiments and were housed in a temperature-controlled vivarium (21Â°C) with a 12/12 hour light-dark cycle.
For lesion experiments 100-150 gm rats were used, while for experiments using anterograde or retrograde transport, the rats weighed 175-200 gm.
Superficial laminar heat lesions
The olfactory tubercle (Tu) was exposed from the lateral side by removing the superficial muscle and bone tissue in the subtemporal region of the head.

If a large enough opening is made, a heated silver plate, attached to a soldering iron, can easily be slipped underneath the Tu and a superficial lesion produced by leaving the silver plate in contact with the surface of the Tu for 2-5 seconds.

By keeping the temperature of the silver plate at about 70Â°C, the blood vessels in the area are usually not severely damaged, which in turn minimizes the risk for bleedings and necroses deep to the superficial lesion.
Another advantage of the laminar coagulation technique is that the size and depth of the lesion can be reasonably well controlled.
Silver impregnation of degeneration
Forty rats were given laminar heat lesions of the Tu.

Following 1-7 days survival time, the animals were perfused and their brains processed for subsequent impregnation with the Fink and Heimer ('67), the cupric silver (de Olmos, '691, or the Gallyas et al. ('80) methods for visualizing degenerating axons and terminals.
Electron microscopy of axonal degeneration
Thirty-three rats were prepared for electron microscopic investigation of degeneration.
Of these, 5 cases were eliminated due to poor preservation and an additional 11 were not analyzed for this experiment because the lesion extended beyond the Tu.
Following the laminar heat lesions in the Tu, the animals were allowed to survive for periods that ranged from 16-72 hours.

Under general anesthesia, the rats were perfused through the ascending aorta with a mixture of 1% paraformaldehyde and 1.25% glutaraldehyde in a 0.12 M sodium phosphate buffer (modified from Karnovsky, '65).
After the perfusion, the brains were exposed and left overnight at 4Â°C in fresh fixative.
Tissue slabs containing the ventral pallidum (VP) were cut by hand or with the vibratome (40 pm) in the frontal plane.
The tissue was rinsed in 5% sucrose buffer, postfixed for one hour in 2% osmium tetroxide in sucrose buffer, dehydrated in graded ethanols, and embedded in araldite or a mixture of epon-araldite.
For light microscopic orientation, 5 pm semithin sections were cut from the blocks and stained either with methylent?
blue-azure I1 (Richardson et al., '60) or with silver for the demonstration of degenerating boutons (Heimer, '70).
Thin sections were cut from areas where degenerating boutons were impregnated.
Lectin injections and immunocytochemistry

Nine rats received iontophoretic injections of phaseolus vulgaris-leuco agglutinin (PHA-L; Vector Labs) at various rostrocaudal levels of the dense cell layer of the Tu and in adjacent loci in the basal forebrain.
Glass micropipettes with tip diameters of 10-20 pm (O.D.)
were pulled from one millimeter (O.D.) glass tubing containing a glass fiber.
PHA-L (2.5% in 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffered saline; pH 7.4; NaPBS) was drawn into the tip of the pipette with suction until the pipette was filled to its shank.
A fine silver wire was immersed in the PHA-L solution in the pipette and attached to the output of a constant voltage stimulator.
The filled pipettes were held in an electrode carrier mounted on a David Kopf micromanipulator.
Under general anesthesia, the scalps of the rats were opened and the return lead for the stimulator was attached to one flap of the wounds.
Electrode placements were made through burr holes in the skull with the aid of the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('82).
Coordinates in the following ranges were used 0.7-2.2 mm in front of the bregma, 1.0-2.2 mm lateral to the midline, and 7.2-8.6 mm beneath the dura.
When the pipette tips were positioned satisfactorily, iontophoretic injections were made with a pulsed 4-5 pA positive current for 15-20 minutes (50% duty cycle and 1 pulse/7 sec).
The current was monitored using a microammeter and held relatively constant by adjusting the output voltage of the stimulator.

After 10 days survival, injected rats were reanesthetized and perfused through the heart, first briefly with a rinse of NaPBS containing 2.5% sucrose and 0.5% procaine hydrochloride, and then with 0.07 M Sorenson s phosphate buffer (SPB) containing 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.1% glutaraldehyde, and 2.5% sucrose.
Following 15-20 minutes of fixation, unbound aldehydes were washed out by perfusing a second time with the rinse solution.
The brains were removed immediately and stored overnight in NaPBS containing 30% sucrose.
The following day, 4 series of 40 pm frozen sections were collected in NaPBS at the sliding microtome.
These were treated with antiserum against (1) PHA-L, (2) glutamate decarboxylase (GAD), or (3) both GAD and PHA-L.
Immunofluorescence microscopy was used to make a rapid assessment of the injection site and transport of the lectin.
Sections prepared for immunofluorescence were incubated for 1 hour in NaPBS containing 0.25% lambda-carrageenan (Sigma), 0.25% Triton X-100 (Sigma), and PHA-L antiserum diluted 1:750 (Vector Labs).

After three quick rinses for a total of 10-15 minutes, the sections were incubated for 1 hour in the same carrier solution containing a 1:lOO dilution of antigoat IgG antiserum conjugated to fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC).
Another quick series of rinses preceded mounting of the sections on pig-gelled glass slides.
The sections were then coverslipped with a 1:3 solution of glycerol and 0.1 M lithium carbonate (pH 11) and immediately viewed using the epifluorescence microscope filtered appropriately for FITC.

In cases where the injection site and transport were judged suitable by immunofluorescence, the rest of the sections were placed in NaPBS containing 0.25% lambda-carrageenan, 0.125% Triton X-100, and either anti-PHA-L (1:2,000) or anti-GAD (1:8,000), or both anti-PHA-L (1:2,000) and anti-GAD (1:8,000) overnight at 4Â°C.

The following morning, the sections were washed 3 times in NaPBS over at least 1 hour and then placed in the same carrier solution containing biotinylated antigoat IgG diluted 1:200 for 1 hour at room temperature.

After another series of 3 rinses over at least 1 hour, the sections were incubated for 1 hour in the same carrier solution containing avidin and biotinylated horseradish peroxidase (KRP), each at a 1:200 dilution.

Another series of rinses preceded a 1-hour incubation at room temperature in a solution of NaPBS (100 ml) containing 50 mg of diaminobenzidine, 40 mg of NH4Cl, 200 mg of P-D-glucose, and 0.4 mg of glucose oxidase (modified from Itoh et al., 79).
Sections were then rinsed again, mounted on slides, and air-dried on a slide warmer.

Immunostaining was intensified by sequential incubations in 0.005% aqueous Os04 for 20-30 minutes, thiocarbohydrazide (0.1 g/lOO ml, 10 minutes), and 0.005% Os04 (10 minutes) with brief intervening rinses in running tap water (C.
Gerfen, personal communication).

Sections were then dehydrated in a graded series of alcohols and lightly counterstained by incubating them in absolute alcohol containing 0.025% toluidine blue for 20-30 minutes, followed by 2 quick dips in absolute alcohol.
They were then cleared in xylene and coverslipped with Permount.
In both this and the following experiment, incubation in the absence of anti-PHA-L, or in the presence of both antiPHA-L and 50 pgiml PHA-L, did not produce staining of cells, axons, or terminals.
The GAD antibody has already been extensively characterized (Oertel et al., 81, 82).
Electron microscopy of anterogradely transported PHA-L
PHA-L was injected into the Tu of 4 rats as described in the preceding paragraph.

Following perfusion with the solutions specified above, the brains were removed immediately and small blocks containing the Tu were sunk in 15% sucrose, frozen in liquid nitrogen, thawed and cut on the Oxford vibratome into 50 pm sections.
Three series of sections were cut.
The first series was subjected to immunofluorescence using PHA-L antiserum as described above to evaluate the success of uptake and transport.

When successful transport was detected, the remaining sections were pooled and placed overnight at 4Â°C in a 1:2,000 dilution of anti-PHA-L in NaPBS containing 0.25% lambda-carrageenan without triton.

The following day the sections were rinsed 3 times in NaPBS over a period of 45 minutes, and placed in buffer containing biotinylated antigoat antibodies (MOO), again rinsed, and placed in buffer containing the avidin-biotin-peroxidase complex (1:200) for 2 hours at room temperature.

The peroxidase was reacted using a modification of the Itoh et al. ( 79) glucose oxidase reaction, and the sections were rinsed, osmicated, and embedded in Araldite 6005 (EMS) on plastic slides with plastic coverslips.
Following polymerization, sections were viewed and photographed with transmitted light.
Areas selected for EM were centered and fastened with Epoxy adhesive to the top of a blank plastic stub.
Thin sections were cut and viewed in a Zeiss 109 electron microscope.
Retrograde labeling with a fluorescent tracer
Under general anesthesia, 6 rats received small injections of the retrograde fluorescent tracer fast blue (Dr.
Illing, West Germany; 10% in 2% dimethyl sulfoxide) aimed at the multiform layer of the Tu.
In order to avoid labeling of the cannula tract, micropipettes with 40-100 pm O.D. were chronically implanted (Alheid and Carlsen, 82) and the tracer allowed to diffuse out.
After 10-14 days survival time, the animals were reanesthetized, and perfused through the ascending aorta.

Following a brief rinse, a twostage fixation was used consisting of 250 ml of a solution containing 1% tannic acid, 4% formaldehyde, and 0.1 M MgS04, followed by 250 ml of an identical fixative but without the tannic acid.
The brains were removed, cryoprotected in 30% sucrose until they sank, and subsequently frozen sectioned on a cryostat at 30 pm.
Two series were saved from every 5 sections and thaw-mounted on gelatinized slides.
One series was coverslipped with DPX (BDH Ltd., England) without further staining or clearing, and the second, adjacent series was counterstained with cresylviolet.

Results.S: RESULTS
the extent of the ventral pallidum ( vp )
intense gad immunoreactivity ( gad - ir ) is coextensive in the forebrain with globus pallidus ( ribak et al . , 79 ) and vp ( zaborszky et al . , 82 young et al . , 84 ) .

parasagittal sections , which pass approximately through the middle of the tu ( fig . l ) , display the maximal extent of the gad - ir continuum and thus serve to illustrate the vp and its continuity with the globus pallidus .
the most ventral part of this continuum forms a distinctly gad immunoreactive stratum of tubercle neuropil , which is oriented horizontally deep to the dense cell layer of the tu .
this stratum is in many places very closely associated with the dense , tubular cell collections of the islands of calleja ( see also fallon et al . , 83 ) .

the gad - ir lamina runs longitudinally between the rostral and caudal tips of the tu , and is joined by the more massive gad - ir ventral extension from the globus pallidus at approximately the midsection of the caudal half of the tu .
at the region of this articulation , ventral pallidum ( vp ) is penetrated by the longitudinally oriented fascicles of the medial forebrain bundle .
Rostrally, the GADIR region descending from the globus pallidus is bounded by the ventral parts of the caudate-putamen and the nucleus accumbens.
its posterior neighbors are the sublenticular substantia innominata dorsally , and elements of the diagonal band system ventrally .
the mediolateral extent of vp is more readily appreciated in coronal sections ( fig . 2 ) .
within the tu the width of vp corresponds to that of the multiform layer of the tu .
dorsomedially elements of vp appear interspersed between the nucleus accumbens and vertical limb of the diagonal band .
The ventral striatopallidal projection originating in the dense cell layer of the olfactory tubercle (Tu)
The following results are based on three different methods that provide independent and complementary demonstrations of the axonal projections originating in the dense cell layer of the Tu.

the silver impregnation of axonal degeneration following superficial heat lesions in the tu produced a reasonably complete picture of the termination areas of the projections from the superficial cell layer of the tu , while the use of the anterogradely transported lectin , pha - l , and the retrograde fluorescent tracer allowed the cells of origin to be reliably identified .
Degeneration studies

superficial heat lesions involving extensive areas of the tu surface ( fig . 3a ) suggested that the most massive projection field of the pathway from the superficial part of the tu is restricted to the vp .
This is clearly demonstrated in parasagittal sections (Fig. 4), where VP can be most easily appreciated.
heavy terminal degeneration was seen in the multiform layer of tu and in the vp immediately dorsal to the medial forebrain bundle , which also exhibits degeneration but primarily in fibers .

sections prepared for electron microscopy ( fig . 5a , b ) demonstrated that following laminar heat lesions , many degenerating boutons appeared in the areas where terminal degeneration was indicated by the presence of argyrophilic particles in the light microscopic analysis .

in other words , vp areas , which showed the presence of terminal degeneration in silver impregnated , semithin plastic embedded sections , were seen to contain a larger number of degenerating boutons characterized primarily by increased electron density of the axoplasm .

the increased density was obvious in many boutons already in animals with 16 - 18 hours survival ( fig . 5a ) , and the boutons often appeared collapsed and surrounded by astroglial processes a few hours later ( fig . 5b ) .

the degenerating boutons were usually scattered among a series of normal boutons , which ensheathed large dendrites like a sleeve in a fashion typical for both dorsal and ventral pallidum ( fox et al . , 74 heimer and wilson , 75 ) .

it came as no surprise that all degenerating boutons seemed to establish symmetric contacts with pallidal dendrites , since that is the typical pattern also for the striatopallidal projection system in the dorsal part of the basal ganglia ( kemp , 70 ) .
the overall distribution of tu fibers projecting to the vp is depicted in figure 6 , which is a diagrammatic representation of the degeneration pattern following a large laminar heat lesion .

due to the proximity of vp to the ventral surface of the tu , it was occasionally difficult to discriminate terminal degeneration from the increased argyrophilia that usually surrounded the experimental lesion .
Nevertheless, it was generally possible, even at rostral levels, to identify terminal degeneration relatively close to the lesion (Fig. 6A).

it should be noted that striatal cell bridges , which extend from the ventral parts of the nucleus accumbens and caudate - putamen to the dense cell layer of the tu and which are a striking cytological feature of the rostral tubercle ( nauta and haymaker , 69 heimer , 781 , were consistently avoided by terminal degeneration ( fig . 6a , b ) .
nor were significant amounts of degeneration found in the ventral parts of accumbens or caudate - putamen .
At more caudal levels, where the VP expands dorsally (Fig. 6B), the lesion was less likely to interfere with the clear recognition of terminal degeneration.

at these levels , where the boundaries between striatal and pallidal territories are pronounced , it was easy to appreciate the fact that the terminal degeneration not only was restricted to , but nearly filled , the ventrolateral part of vp .
indeed , the massive terminal degeneration stops abruptly along an undulating curved line that defines the ventral boundary of the caudate - putamen .
near the caudal tip of the tu , the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band ( hdb ) makes its appearance ( fig . 6c ) .
Significant accumulations of terminal degeneration appeared both below and above the HDB, which appeared not to contain terminal degeneration.
On the dorsolateral aspect of the HDB, the terminal degeneration formed a characteristic cap (arrow in Figs. 6C, 71, which ended rather abruptly just caudal to this level.

bands of terminal degeneration , representing pallidal bridges , could be observed to sweep around the lateral edge of the hdb ( fig . 6c ) to establish continuity with terminal degeneration in the multiform layer of the tu below the hdb .
whereas the degeneration above the hdb could be appreciated as typical terminal degeneration , that below the hdb appeared to include both terminals and axons of passage .

above and below hdb , terminal degeneration stopped abruptly at the caudal tip of the tu , but degenerating axons could be followed dorsally to the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus ( md ) , and often in the medial forebrain bundle to more caudal parts of the lateral hypothalamus , including the nuclei gemini .
Although it was not a particular focus of this experiment, we did not see evidence for terminations in the mesencephalon.
pha - l studies
one of the advantages of the pha - l method is its ability to demonstrate cell morphology at the origin of the pathway under study ( gerfen and sawchenko , 84 ) .
this feature is of particular value in the tu , where striatal and pallidal cell territories are often intermingled .
the approximate location of the pha - l injection in the superficial dense cell layer of the tu is indicated in figure 3b .

following injection of pha - l into the dense cell layer of the tu , clusters of neurons displaying a golgilike impregnation of immunoreactive product marked the centers of the injection sites ( fig . 8 ) .
The clusters typically were 100300 pm in diameter and were located near the centers of spherical or ovoid halos of variably dense, diffusely deposited reaction product.
The halos were generally 200-500 pm in diameter.
Impregnated dendrites radiated through the zones of diffusely deposited reaction product, and fully impregnated perikarya could commonly be observed near the periphery of the diffusely labeled zone.
the morphological detail exhibited by pha - l impregnation rivals that of a golgi impregnation .
this was particularly illustrated by neurons at some distance from the central cluster , which , hence , were relatively unobscured by other impregnated neural elements .
for example , injections centered in the medium - sized cell territories of the tu revealed dendrites that were studded with dendritic spines .
This feature can be appreciated even in the low magnification photograph in Figure 8A.

injection of pha - l into the plexiform layer of the tu often resulted in the impregnation of neurons in the dense cell layer and most superficial part of multiform layer , which appeared to represent a single morphological class resembling the striatal medium spiny neuron ( e . g . , kemp and powell , 71 chang et al . , 82 ) with a diameter of 10 - 20 pm , and dendrites that radiated from the impregnated neurons in all directions .

Many dendrites were oriented perpendicular to the pial surface of the Tu, and they appeared to extend ventrally all the way into the plexiform layer, even when the impregnated cells were located deep in the multiform layer.
in fact , we were never successful in impregnating only neurons of the dense cell layer , even when the pha - l appeared to have been deposited in the plexiform layer .
following less superficial injections of pha - l involving deeper layers of the tu , more than one morphological class of neurons frequently exhibited the characteristic golgilike impregnation .

in addition to the medium - sized , putatively striatal neurons , medium to large ( 15 - 25 pm ) fusiform neurons were observed , which typically had 3 to 5 large primary dendrites , which extended relatively long distances from the impregnated perikarya with little or moderate amounts of branching .
These resembled pallida1 -type neurons (Millhouse and Heimer, 84; Iwahori and Mizuno, 80) and were present in VP-territories of the Tu.

since the sections stained with pha - l could be conveniently alternated with sections stained for gad , the positions of impregnated cells as well as their terminal fields identified in the pha - l section could be matched with the topographic distribution of ventral pallidal areas as revealed by gad - ir on nearby sections ( fig . 9 ) .
The light microscopic appearance of anterogradely transported PHAL consisted of a large number of isolated puncta, many of which were joined by threadlike interconnections (Fig. 9B).

following restricted injections in the superficial part of the tu , such areas of terminal labeling were invariably identified in neighboring parts of vp , usually with additional terminal labeling in more remote caudodorsal areas of vp ( figs . 10 , 11 ) .

electron microscopic observations confirmed that the puncta seen in the light microscope were indeed labeled boutons in contact with typical pallidallike dendrites ( fig . 5c see also zahm and heimer , 85 ) .
another striking feature is presented by the appearance of terminal labeling among the fascicles of the medial forebrain bundle ( mfb ) .
this phenomenon is easily understood when one realizes that ventral pallidal components invade the area of the mfb .

Indeed, one of the most obvious topographical relations of the rostra1 part of the MFB is represented by its close relations to the VP, which in many places completely surrounds the fascicles of the MFB (Zaborszky et al., 86).

this is most easily appreciated in gad - stained sections ( fig . 9a ) , which were prepared as complement to the pha - l sections , and for the purpose of outlining in detail ventral pallidal areas .

this close correlation of anterogradely transported pha - l with the areas of ventral pallidum in nearby sections stained for gad provided convincing demonstration of the termination of the ventral striatopallidal pathway within vp areas surrounding the fascicles of the mfb .
fibers ending in vp appeared to represent the entire projection of the superficial dense cell layer of the tu .

when injections were less superficial and involved larger cells in the multiform layer , long projections to known pallidal targets such as mediodorsal thalamic nucleus and substantia nigra were observed in addition to the projections just described .

in addition , control injections placed in the nucleus accumbens resulted in anterograde transport of the lectin to a number of targets including vp , lateral hypothalamus , the ventral tegmental area , and substantia nigra , as well as cell groups in tegmentum of the pons and medulla .

if the absence of downstream projections following superficial pha - l injections in the tu is the result of inadequate transport of the lectin by those cells , there was no evidence that nearby cells in the vp and other parts of the ventral striatum shared the deficiency .
Labeling with retrograde tracers
Because of its limited dorsocaudal extent, the multiform layer of the Tu proved difficult to hit without direct involvement of nearby laminae and structures including the accumbens or the HDB.
only 2 of the 6 injections were well centered within the multiform layer of the tu .
In these, the rostrocaudal extent of the injection site was quite limited with no tracer deposit in the overlying pipette track.

an injection centered in the multiform layer of the tu labeled almost the entire rostrocaudal extent of the dense cell layer ( arrow in fig . 12b ) , while labeling in the mediolateral dimension was more confined .
as expected from our anterograde experiments , most labeled neurons were in the dense cell layer of the tubercle , with many fewer and more scattered neurons in the deeper layers .

of course , at more rostral levels , labeled neurons in the deeper layers of the tubercle may represent cells labeled through axons traversing the injection site enroute to thalamus or caudal hypothalamus .

consistent with our anterograde experiments and with observations in golgi material ( see below ) , many neurons in caudal tu were labeled by rostral tracer injections , indicating the rostral course taken by their axons before terminating in more dorsal regions of vp .
Topography of the ventral striatopallidal projection originating in the olfactory tubercle
There is a definite mediolateral topography in the ventral striatopallidal projection originating in the striatal parts of the Tu.
in other words , small superficial laminar heat lesions give rise to areas of dense terminal degeneration in vp immediately deep to the lesion ( see fig . 13 ) .

if the dense cell layer and the overlying horizontal lamina of vp are imagined as planar structures marked with coordinate grids in the rostrocaudal and mediolateral dimensions , the origins and most dense terminations of projections from the dense cell layer to suprajacent vp are located in corresponding positions on the respective grids .
This is especially the case for the rostral three-fourths of the Tu.

furthermore , from each locus of dense termination within the horizontal lamina of vp , an additional more moderate number of fibers extend caudally to terminate within the pallidal core of the tu or to ascend to more dorsal parts of the vp along the same parasagittal coordinate , diminishing gradually in more caudal sections ( figs . 10 , ll ) .

an interesting phenomenon , first observed in golgi studies ( millhouse and heimer , ' 84 ) , is that many of the fibers originating in the superficial caudolateral part of the tu first sweep forward in a rostrally convex curve to circumvent the hdb before turning caudally to end in more dorsal parts of the vp .
This projection is illustrated in Figures 6C and 7, in which the terminal degeneration forms a characteristic cap immediately above the HDB.

the projection fibers from the caudomedial part of the dense cell layer are somewhat exceptional in the sense that they have a tendency to sweep laterally and to some extent even rostrally to terminations in ventral pallidal areas within the multiform layer .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The olfactory tubercle (Tu) of the rat has traditionally been conceived of as part of the olfactory cortex, and there has generally been little effort to recognize different subterritories in the tubercle when its extrinsic connections have been examined.

Indeed, surveys (e.g., Stephan, '75) of the available literature on Tu connections have implied that the tubercle is an integral part of the neighboring olfactory (piriform) cortex in the sense that its extrinsic connections seemed to be reminiscent of those of the olfactory cortex.

The similarities between the two structures were perceived particularly on the basis of their efferent connections, which according to most accounts were restricted primarily to nearby olfactory related structures such as the olfactory bulb, retrobulbar areas, amygdaloid body, and periamygdaloid cortex, as well as the medial septum-diagonal band complex.

Efferent fibers from both the Tu and olfactory cortex, furthermore, were generally thought to be incorporated in the medial forebrain bundle and destined to reach the lateral preoptic-hypothalamic continuum and the nuclei gemini, as well as the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus.
It should be said in all fairness that the above description of the Tu projections was based primarily on the study of normal anatomical material and experimental silver impregnation studies.
Modern tracer techniques have only occasionally been applied to the study of the Tu connections, but when they have, the results have not been altogether consistent with the preceding schemes.

For instance, an associative pathway from the tubercle to neighboring olfactory or periamygdaloid cortices, which one might reasonably have expected if the Tu is an integral part of the primary olfactory cortex, has not been confirmed (e.g., Haberly and Price, '78).
Nor has much evidence come forward in support of a significant pathway from the Tu to the septum-diagonal band complex.

It also seems clear from retrograde tracing experiments that the cells projecting from the Tu to bulbar or retrobulbar areas are located, not in the Tu proper, but among the fascicles of the medial forebrain bundle deep to the tubercle (e.g., Dennis and Kerr, '76; de Olmos et al., '78; Zaborszky et al., '86).

A pathway from the region of the Tu to the nuclei gemini in the posterolateral part of the hypothalamus is well established (Lundberg, '60; Scott and Leonard, '71; Heimer, '72; Scott and Chafh, '75), but the identity and exact location of the cells projecting to the nuclei gemini is not well specified.

Nor is much known about the Tu projection to the lateral preoptic-hypothalamic continuum, although the existence of such projections was implicit in terms such as the "deep olfactory radiation" (Dhjerine, 1895) and the "olfactohypothalamic system" (Herrick, '10).

More recent Golgi studies (e.g., Valverde-Garcia, '65; Millhouse, '69) have perpetuated this notion, but studies employing experimental silver methods (e.g., Scott and Leonard, '71) have not produced much evidence for the existence of a projection from the Tu to the lateral preoptic-hypothalamic area.

There is one olfactory tubercle projection, however, whose cells of origin have been positively identified, namely the projection to the mediodorsal thalamus (e.g., Siege1 et al., '77; Benjamin et al., '82; Price and Slotnick, '83).

Using a combination of fluorescent retrograde tracers and immunohistochemical techniques, Young et al. ('84) have convincingly shown that the Tu projection to mediodorsal thalamus originates from cells located in those parts of the Tu, which in have been identified as the VP on the basis of GAD-IR.

Since many of these neurons also appear to have ultrastrucTu tural characteristics typical for pallidal neurons, we have proposed that this Tu pathway represents part of a general the pallidothalamic projection system rather than a corticothalamic pathway (Young et al., '84; Zahm et al., '86). the The ventral pallidum (VP)
In sagittal sections, the globus pallidus is conventionally identified as a triangular structure above and behind the anterior commissure.
It is characteristically penetrated by the bundles of the internal capsule.

The rostroventral borthe der of the globus pallidus underneath the anterior commisa sure has really never been well defined, which in retrospect out is not surprising, since there is now considerable evidence that such a border does not exist at this level.
Rather, the cytoarchitectural and histochemical features, which are accepted as typically pallidal, extend as a continuum to more the rostroventral parts of the forebrain.

We have referred to this rostroventral extension of dense GAD-IR, which passes downward and forward into the multiform layer of the Tu the as the "ventral pallidum" (Heimer, '78; Switzer, et al., '82). ary The VP appears to be composed of neurons similar, if not the identical in morphology, to those in globus pallidus.
Most important in the context of the present report is that VP seems to receive a well-organized and dense input from striatallike neurons in nucleus accumbens and olfactory tubercle.

The projection from nucleus accumbens to the the portion of VP immediately ventral to the anterior commissure is well documented (Wilson, '72; Swanson and Cowan, '75; Nauta et al., '78; Zaborszky et al., '82; Haber and in Nauta, '83; Mogenson et al., '83; Groenewegen and a Russchen, '841, while the projection from Tu to VP was only reported in preliminary form (Heimer and Wilson, '75; Goldschmidt and Heimer, '80; Zaborszky et al., '82) prior to the present paper.

Together, the efferents from nucleus a accumbens and from the dense cell layer of the Tu completely outline the VP, which may be independently described by histochemistry for iron (Switzer et al., '82), or immunohistochemistry for GAD, substance P, enkephalin, epidermal growth factor, or ferritin (Haber and Nauta, '81, to '83; Zaborszky et al., '82; Young et al., '84; Fallon et al., '84; Martin et al., '851, and by retrograde labeling after large injections in mediodorsal thalamus (Young et al., '84).
The results of the present experiments strengthen the concept of the ventral striatopallidal system, while providing additional details about the subdivision represented by the Tu.
The ventral striatopallidal projection originating in the striatal cell territories of the olfactory tubercle
General distribution.

It has now become apparent that the Tu represents the most ventral component of the corpus striatum and that it contains both ventral striatal and ventral pallidal cell territories (see review by Heimer et al., '85).

The complicated cytology of the Tu, however, which features extensive interdigitations of the various neuronal populations and which has been described in detail by Millhouse and Heimer ('841, has conspired against forming definite conclusions regarding the relations of the striatal and pallidal components of the Tu.

When attempting to interpret the results obtained in this study, it is important to realize that the medium-sized densely spined striatal cells the superficial dense cell layer are so numerically predominant that the superficial laminar heat lesions of the were likely to involve predominantly striatal cells, especially if the lesions were confined to restricted areas of tubercle (see below).

The laminar heat lesions were often well demarcated in silver impregnated sections and surrounding tissue well preserved, which made it possible in most instances to discriminate between terminal degeneration and degenerating fibers of passage even in regions close to the lesion.

As witnessed by the dense terminal degeneration obtained after superficial but extensive Tu lesions (Figs. 4,6), ventral striatopallidal pathway originating in the 'hi is prominent projection system, which terminates throughthe main ventral and lateral parts of the VP.

In other words, its projection field is in general restricted to the areas of VP that are located immediately above the Tu, thereby leaving the dorsomedial parts of the VP free for projections from the accumbens.
The dense terminal degeneration, furthermore, is strictly confined to the VP.

This is convincingly demonstrated in Figure 4, in which area of terminal degeneration exhibits a sharp boundboth toward the caudate-putamen (CPu) dorsally and to nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band (HDB) ventrally.

The HDB, however, does contain degeneration, which has the character of degenerating axons of passage, and it is a reasonable assumption that they represent, in large part at least, degenerating fibers on route to MD, nuclei gemini, and possibly other areas of the upper brainstem.

The series of more restricted laminar heat lesions, as well as the PHA-L injections, which were placed various parts of the Tu, served to confirm the presence of prominent and well-defined ventral striatopallidal projection system within the Tu.

Although the heavily corrugated dense cell layer reaches the surface of the Tu in several places, it was nevertheless possible in some cases to avoid more extensive involvement of the deep multiform layer when making the small laminar heat lesions.

Degenerating fibers and terminal degeneration in such instances were restricted to ventral pallidal areas in the Tu region, and there was little or no sign of degeneration in Tu pathways the mediodorsal thalamus or nuclei gemini, which was typically the case if the multiform layer with its content of pallidallike large cells had been included in the lesion.

The results obtained by the PHA-L method provided some additional insight, which cannot generally be obtained by studying the pattern of degenerating axons and axon terminals as a result of experimental lesions.

The most obvious advantage of the PHA-L method in this study was fact that the injection in several cases appeared to have involved only medium-sized densely spined neurons in the superficial part of the Tu.
Such injections resulted in transport of PHA-L to axon terminals that were located entirely within the boundaries of pallidal domains as identified by GAD immunocytochemistry on adjacent sections.

Although is usually difficult to exclude the possibility that PHA-L has been taken up by fibers passing through the injection site, the likelihood for this type of complication is quite remote in this case, especially since the injection is located the surface of the brain.
Furthermore, there was never any evidence of terminal labeling in the MD unless large pallidallike neurons had been labeled in the area of the injections.
The initial report by Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84), finally, tend to show that labeling of fibers of passage does not occur when using the PHA-L method.
Topography in the ventral striatopallidal pathway originating in the olfactory tubercle

A significant finding of the present investigation is that the mediolateral topography of the dense cell layer is maintained by the ventral striatopallidal projection originating in the dense cell layer of the Tu.
However, the projection is characterized by a significant spread in the rostrocaudal direction.
This was clearly demonstrated both in cases with small laminar heat lesions and with restricted PHA-L injections.
Indeed, even the experiments in which a retrograde tracer was centered in themultiform layer of the Tu tended to support this notion.

In other words, the number of retrogradely labeled cells in the dense cell layer decreased rather rapidly in a lateral and medial direction away from the injection, while practically the entire rostrocaudal extent of the dense cell layer was marked by retrograde cell labeling in parasagittal sections (Fig. 12).

Clearly, these retrograde tracing experiments are of limited value by themselves, but they do provide some valuable information and, as in this case, even a striking illustration of some of the main features of the ventral striatopallidal pathway when considered in conjunction with the results obtained by the anterograde tracer methods used in this study.
"he topographic pattern described above is most clearly revealed with the PHA-L method as illustrated schematically in Figures 10 and 11.

Injections of PHA-L, especially in the rostral one-half to three-fourths of the superficial part of the Tu, give rise to terminal labeling that is especially dense directly above in the VP of the multiform layer.
In addition, there is a considerable spread of the projection in the sagittal plane, especially in caudal direction.
Hence, successively caudal primary projections are supplemented by moderate secondary projections from more rostral parts of the tubercle.

The spread of the terminations of the ventral striatopallidal fibers in a rostrocaudal direction is reminiscent of the spread of the striatopallidal fibers described by Chang et al. ('81) in the dorsal part of the basal ganglia.

The presence of PHA-L labeled terminals among the fascicles of the MFB (Fig. 9) no doubt reflects the fact that the MFB penetrates the ventral pallidal territory deep to the Tu, and in some places even appears to separate, at least partly, the most ventral territory of the VP (that part located in the multiform layer of the Tu) from the rest of the VP.

This would seem to explain the rather common appearance of two main foci or patches of labeled terminals or of terminal degeneration, one below and another above the fascicles of the MFB, especially in cases where the PHA-L injection or the heat lesion was restricted to the more caudal parts of the Tu.

That this phenomenon is most easily revealed in cases with caudal lesions can be explained by the fact that it is only at this rostrocaudal level that VP shows a significant expansion in a dorsal direction above the MFB (Figs. 1, 2).

Indeed, the most pronounced demonstration of two major separate terminal fields occurs at the extreme caudal part of the Tu, at which point the HDB rather than the MF'B separates the pallidal region in the multiform layer of the Tu from the main dorsal expanse of pallidum (e.g., Figs. 6C, 7, 13A).

The idealized drawing in Figure 14B is intended to illustrate the close topographic relations that exist between the HDB, MF'B, and VP, and to portray in a schematic fashion the general organization of the ventral striatopallidal system originating in the Tu.
